item.title: Ticket #2141 (Serve XHTML properly) updated
item.dc:creator: masquerade
item.description:
XHTML 1.0 does not have to be sent with as text/html and still be perfectly valid, which WordPress currently does. Until the default templates are XHTML 1.1 or a majority of the browsing market can accept XML mime-types, there really is no reason to incorperate them, and it will undoubtably cause trouble for the people trying to make their own custom templates, as XML parsing is /very/ strict where XHTML is not. One typo and the page won't even display. If anyone wants to add this to their won templates, they can feel free.

-1 for this, wait for IE to do it right, instead of working around it

item.title: Changeset [3346]: Typo.
item.dc:creator: ryan
item.description: Typo.

item.title: Ticket #2141 (Serve XHTML properly) created
item.dc:creator: rolandog
item.description:
I searched but didn't find much related to serving xhtml as application/xhtml+xml and having it work in IE. I found â€‹this article a few days ago (while wondering how to serve xhtml properly, so that IE6 doesn't attempt to download the document).

My question is "why hasn't this been featured properly in the default template?"

Since Wordpress is all about compliance, I guess we owe it to WP to make our documents REALLY valid. The article explains how to serve a document in XHTML with the proper mimetype of application/xhtml+xml (if the browser supports it) or in plain ol' HTML strict as text/html.

If anyone wants to add this functionality, you just have to save the script into a file called 'mimetype.php', then include it in your template instead of the html element tag. Like this: 

<?php include (TEMPLATEPATH . "/mimetype.php"); ?>
   <head>
      ...
   </head>
   <body>
      ...
   </body>
</html>

I'm currently using the 'fix'... and so is the guy from the article, so I feel if there is a workaround for the IE issue, lets use it.

item.title: Ticket #2136 (Edit post doesn't show completed trackbacks) created
item.dc:creator: pirateking
item.description:
Code in the edit-form-advanced references $pinged instead of: $post->pinged 

if ('' != $post->pinged) {
	$pings .= '<p>'. __('Already pinged:') . '</p><ul>';
	$already_pinged = explode("\n", trim($post->pinged));
	foreach ($already_pinged as $pinged_url) {
		$pings .= "\n\t<li>$pinged_url</li>";
	}
	$pings .= '</ul>';
}

Also, it would be nice to do a second loop, showing posts to be pinged because of the new trackback method.

item.title: Ticket #2135 (trim() plugin details) created
item.dc:creator: Viper007Bond
item.description:
The plugin details were sometimes (and the URIs always) were having line breaks and such in them. This makes sure all plugin details created by get_plugin_data() are trim()'ed.

I noticed this while using the function for a plugin of mine and it was bugging me that some of the outputted details had line breaks in them.

item.title: Ticket #2134 (consolidating get_userdata() and get_userdatabylogin()) created
item.dc:creator: johnjosephbachir
item.description: Here is a patch which consolidates logic in the two functions get_userdata() and get_userdatabylogin(). If get_userdatabylogin() does not find the user in the cache, it has get_userdata() do the rest. The number of database queries remains the same in all usage cases.

	if (preg_match('%^<!--[^>-]+-->$%', $string))
		return $string;
	# Allow HTML comments

item.title: Ticket #2130 (wp_kses kills < !-- more --> from xmlrpc posted entries) updated
item.dc:creator: tsimmons
item.description:
Okay, after more digging, I found it is in wp_kses_split2() on line 101: 

if (!preg_match('%^<\s*(/\s*)?([a-zA-Z0-9]+)([^>]*)>?$%', $string, $matches))

This always strips the <!--more--> tags. My regular expression skillz are way down right now (mighty tired after long night ...)

Sorry I can't offer a fix right off ...

item.title: Ticket #2112 (Backup save to server does not save file) updated
item.dc:creator: skippy
item.description:
The backup appeared normal and the link to the file download worked but there was no file in the directory.

Does this mean that you were able to download the backup file when it was sent to your browser? If so, the very next thing the plugin does is to delete the file from the server. Once you've downloaded it, there's no reason for it to live on the server.

item.title: Ticket #2130 (wp_kses kills < !-- more --> from xmlrpc posted entries) created
item.dc:creator: tsimmons
item.description:
I couldn't find the exact point where it happens, but somewhere when XMLRPC posted entries are being processed, the

<!--more-->

tags are being stripped which gets rid of the "more..." link and instead displays the entire post on the indexes. I tracked it down to somewhere in the nested functions called in kses.php, somewhere after line 55: 

	return wp_kses_split($string, $allowed_html_fixed, $allowed_protocols);

item.title: Ticket #2125 (dbx cookies conflict with mod_security?) updated
item.dc:creator: dougal
item.description:
Priority changed

More info. I *think* that this might be caused by the fact that I upgraded my mod_security from 1.8.x to 1.9.x recently.

The mod_security SecFilterCheckCookieFormat directive has been deprecated, but was still present in my httpd_conf file. I replaced that with the SecFilterNormalizeCookies directive, and things seem to be okay now.

I'm resetting the priority of this ticket to low, and if nobody else hears about this type of problem soon, feel free to close it out.

item.title: Ticket #2125 (dbx cookies conflict with mod_security?) created
item.dc:creator: dougal
item.description:
I'm having an issue where a cookie set by the dbx.js libraries are causing mod_security to deny access to my pages. When this occurs, if I delete the 'dbx-postmeta' cookie from my browser, everything returns to normal.

Until I visit my Write page again. Has anybody else seen this?

Example content of the dbx-postmeta cookie:

grabit=0-,1-,2-,3-,4-,5-,6-&advancedstuff=0-,1-,2-
